"if the government recognizes a marriage performed in some churches as legal, then the government should recognize a marriage performed by any church as legal."

Choosing among churches, one recognized by the government and another not, is what the First Amendment was intended to prohibit with, "Congress shall make no law respecting an establishment of religion" one over the other, "or prohibiting the free exercise thereof" by accepting the ceremony of one as correct and declaring the ceremony of another incorrect.

The Court need not get to anything newer than the literal words of the First Amendment.

First time I heard of issues with stored blood was in a documentary called "Primum Non Nocere".

MD Stamler said in the movie: "We like to say that the respiratory cycle is really a three-gas system. The handbook of respiratory physiology, the classic text, will include our model of a three-gas respiratory cycle. So we missed a gas. Hemoglobin doesn’t just ferry oxygen from lungs to tissues and CO2 back, carbon dioxide, back to the lungs but it carries this third gas, nitric oxide, in a protected form and it releases the nitric oxide together with oxygen. The nitric oxide then dilates the blood vessels so that the oxygen can get to the tissues.
What turns out is that our blood banks are deficient in nitric oxide."

I'm happy to see this topic now reaching the public.

I am a medical massage therapist and have worn vibram shoes to run, hike and weight train for 5 years. Because of my own experience with my feet and the feet of the clients I work on, I can everyone has a foot problem in one way or another. For the thick soled shoes wearers I see a lot of metatarsal displacement, tarsal compression, atrophied muscle and connective tissues and over lack of stability. I am not seeing that in my barefoot shoe wears. I do see stress fractures, myofasical tears, and strain related injuries but lets think about this, these shoes have only been on the market for about 10 years or so and the majority of my clients have been wearing them for less than 3 years. 10 weeks is not enough of an adjustment period for a change this extreme. There is going to be some transitional, growing pains as the person adjust to using their bodies in way not before used. It is also mentioned that that the control group that kept to their shoes had a ongoing edema level of 1? How is that explained? Shoes you are comfortable in should not be giving you edema. Especially when do an activity such as running that increases circulation return. Should you heel land run on concert in barefoot technology? Of course not! But one can argue that you should heel land at all. Can't run spring style in the front of the foot in heavy, thick soled shoes.

It is the client's business -- unless he or she is going endlessly to a therapist as a substitute for developing intimacy with non-professionals, then expecting the insurance business (and, by implication, the wider populace) to chip in endlessly.

Amen!

Wisdom in a therapist....good God, how revolutionary.

In my little opinion, our modern world has too few grandmothers and mentors and (true) best friends, and we listen to them too seldom. CBT felt like mind games to me, and I felt only more depressed after sessions. My counselor was good, but it always felt like she was struggling to hear *me* through the filter of CBT. Undoubtedly CBT and other regimens help many people, but that doesn't mean that they should be instituted everywhere! Many of us ail precisely because of this sort of approach which overlooks the human being in the patient.

An example of harmful intervention is rapid debriefing, wherein a traumatized person is asked to recall and review the traumatic events.
This has been deemed harmful.

ADDITIONAL COMMENT: Since many disorders (both physical and 'psychological' -- and many involve both... Many go into natural remission without any intervention... If a patient is in treatment, it is likely for the therapist to take credit for it. This can confound any attempt for validation.

It appears that like religious people quoting the Bible to justify their own beliefs and prejudices, the therapists posting here are doing the same. What is a person looking for help to do?

My own experiences in my practice lead me to believe that CBT works. I cannot tell you now many clients have expressed their gratitude to me for giving them tools for change as opposed to simply giving them insight but without a way to fix the problem.

The title of this article is misleading. It pretty much covers only one cause of hearing loss--noise. The reality is that hearing loss is caused by many different things. Ten percent of white Caucasians are afflicted with otosclorosis. That's a lot of people to overlook. Otosclorosis is the abnormal growth of bone or calcification on the middle ear stapes bones. It is a progressive disease with progressive hearing loss, usually in both ears. The growth on those tiny bones prevent their movement. Movement of those bones is imperative for hearing. The condition affects male and female but is predominantly female. No one knows the cause and there is no cure, only hearing aids and/or surgery can help but doesn't cure.

An overlooked cause for many many health problems, disorders and diseases is hypothyroidism that is not treated sufficiently. Too bad I'm not a medical doctor or researcher. If I were I would achieve fame for medical breakthroughs. Under-treated Hypothyroidism is a root cause of otosclorosis hearing loss. The hypothyroid medical establishment which basks in accolades is the cause of this problem for several generations now. Hypothyroidism is one of the most complex and devastating diseases. There are more or less 28 million cases in the U.S., mostly women by far. Ninety-Nine percent of the doctors in this field are incompetent, and despite the existing science and facts, keep their hypothyroidism patients under-replaced (under-treated). More in my next post.

Continued from my previous post:

As I mentioned undertreated Hypothyroidism patients can develop otosclorosis hearing loss. They are put on some medication but not enough to keep them well enough or their disease from progressing and causing other serious and nuisance problems.

Some theories say that diabetes causes otosclorosis. However, no one in the world knows what causes diabetes. There are approximately the same number of people with diabetes as there are with hypothyroidism. Diabetes is called an epidemic while hypothyroidism isn't and is barely even known by people who don't have it. Hypothyroidism generally will lead to diabetes not the other way around.

There is a vast vast disconnect in the medical field. The dots are just not being connected. Wish I had a funded research lab, staff and supplies at my disposal, ah, also the right credentials.

Good luck to everyone with hearing loss. It is a very difficult way to go through life. You are all to be commended for trying your best. My recommendation for everyone is that you use your hearing aids, because not using them leads to other serious problems...

"Also, maybe passersby could step into some of these noisy restaurants and tell a staff person "We were tempted to try the food here, but the music is so loud it would make conversation difficult." Then walk out."

I've done this, also asked that the volume of music be turned down. Occasionally the music will be turned down, but most people who run restaurants don't seem to care much whether the noise keeps you away or bothers you. I've had a few people tell me: oh, it's management policy to keep it this loud and we can't change that.

The supermarkets in my area are particularly bad, so bad that sometimes a checker will say they can't hear my answer if they ask a question. Again, I've repeatedly asked that the music volume be turned down, no luck. I've had people tell me they don't even notice it. I live in a fairly small town, there are 3 supermarkets, all w/loud muzak/music.

That's another reason I now do just about all of my food shopping at a food co-op--they'll turn the volume down if you ask if it happens to be loud. Supermarkets are just for stuff the co-op either doesn't carry or the price is high (toilet paper, etc.).
Reel lawnmowers (no engine) are probably easier then scythes for many to use.   I use one, it's quiet, although a scythe is better for cutting tall grass and some thick stemmed weeds.

One musician told me he was required to use electronic amplification--this was in large room (of a restaurant) where acoustic guitar (no amplication) would've provided more than enough "sound".

My impression is that some people are so habituated to noise (lots of decibels) that they feel odd/upset when it's quieter.

Also think that many people don't like the noise levels but don't want to be bothered complaining or asking that the volume be turned down.

True re: people blasting music but it seems that all that will happen is that the volume will be cranked up even more.

It's interesting that there's been (supposedly) more interest in mindfulness meditation as that generally calls for a little time in a quiet place.

On the other hand, Yoga Journal has had several articles re: use of music when doing yoga and while it's not been said directly, my guess it that the volume of the music is LOUD. Seems incompatible w/yoga to me, but perhaps not "competitive" yoga.

I wish OSHA would govern my occupation. I am a flight attendant at one of the largest airlines in the world. However, we fall under the guidelines within the Railroad Act. These guidelines mean we have no limited workday, no required rest period, no required breaks for things like a meal. I guess the FAA is suppose to watch after us, but they have never tested our planes for noise.  Some of our airplanes are so  incredibly loud (and old), that I can't understand the passenger's drink orders.  During the day I tend to read their lips, but on the dark night flights it is incredibly hard. Unfortunately, I now have recurrent earaches and have burst my eardrum several times due to pressurization.  After 17 years in this occupation, I feel I will definitely be wearing hearing aids sooner or later. I guess in today's world of constant noise, maybe It won't be so bad.  After all my grandmother hasn't been able to hear for 61 years, and she will be celebrating her 107th birthday in June!
